commit_message:
Passing auth_url to keystoneclient.authenticate

During the creation of a trust, our Keystone client implementation calls
the authenticate method which fails due to the auth_url parameter is
missing. Seems that the current V3 Kestone client isn't honoring the auth_url
passed during initialization.
If you call the authenticate method without passing the auth_url
parameter, the authentication fails because that parameter was not
properly set, but should work because that parameter is passed during
initialization.
This commit tries to fix the issue until a patch from Keystone lands to
master.

Change-Id: Id242dcac31fe535836033dff951844a66bcc2100
Closes-Bug: #1326066

subject: Fix data migration script error
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-06-06 07:58:11.000000000', 'files': ['barbican/model/migration/alembic_migrations/versions/13d127569afa_create_secret_store_metadata_table.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/barbican/commit/08c63fdbcb22978290fc4f67c648708cc2d7ebd6', 'message': 'Fix data migration script error

There are two types of data migration:
1. Automatic - happens during barbican api startup
2. Manual - run on demand when migration is required

The Manual step is done by running the bin/barbican-db-manage.py
script. This script fails with an "UnboundExecutionError" due
to a conflict between SQLAlchemy synching vs Alembic version
processing in checking for the existence of the table. This commit
fixes the issue by replacing the SQLAlchemy metadata calls with
alembic calls by reusing the context/connection from the existing
"op".

Change-Id: I9bf65594a9e76b3f98d67bbd47a9cc7b97298de0
Closes-Bug: #1326654
'}]
commit_message:
Fix data migration script error

There are two types of data migration:
1. Automatic - happens during barbican api startup
2. Manual - run on demand when migration is required

The Manual step is done by running the bin/barbican-db-manage.py
script. This script fails with an "UnboundExecutionError" due
to a conflict between SQLAlchemy synching vs Alembic version
processing in checking for the existence of the table. This commit
fixes the issue by replacing the SQLAlchemy metadata calls with
alembic calls by reusing the context/connection from the existing
"op".

Change-Id: I9bf65594a9e76b3f98d67bbd47a9cc7b97298de0
Closes-Bug: #1326654

unit test coverage.

subject: Move check for disk-image-get-kernel
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-06-02 17:59:10.000000000', 'files': ['scripts/load-image'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-incubator/commit/35add03471303e89f5399750ee706c6c4dc242e1', 'message': "Move check for disk-image-get-kernel

disk-image-get-kernel is only used if the vmlinuz and initrd are not
present in the directory with the image file. So there's no need to
check it's path which results in noise to the user with a big echo of
$PATH unless we intend to use it.

Change-Id: Ic972cb1ff5e9a1ccf5be07ed64af588059a3c6a5
"}]
commit_message:
Move check for disk-image-get-kernel

disk-image-get-kernel is only used if the vmlinuz and initrd are not
present in the directory with the image file. So there's no need to
check it's path which results in noise to the user with a big echo of
$PATH unless we intend to use it.

Change-Id: Ic972cb1ff5e9a1ccf5be07ed64af588059a3c6a5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-incubator refs/changes/02/97302/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: DIGK=$(which disk-image-get-kernel || echo $DIB_PATH/bin/disk-image-get-kernel) if [ ! -e $DIGK ]; then echo "Error: unable to locate disk-image-get-kernel" exit 1 fi
deleted_lines: DIGK=$(which disk-image-get-kernel || echo $DIB_PATH/bin/disk-image-get-kernel) if [ ! -e $DIGK ]; then echo "Error: unable to locate disk-image-get-kernel" exit 1 fi

commit_message:
adding cornercases for set_metadata

   Agregate_set_metadata leaves users confused because it currently
   does not check for duplicate key=value parameters for addition
   or a missing key for deletion. All that user sees is that "metadata has been updated"
   more details in bug1292572

   This patch checks for above mentioned corner cases and informs users when and why
   there was no change made in above corner cases

   Closes-Bug: #1292572

Change-Id: I522c847643cfeb172c81853b7360410a9bb66b19
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-novaclient refs/changes/23/98423/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: currentmetadata = getattr(aggregate, 'metadata', {}) if set(metadata.items()) & set(currentmetadata.items()): raise exceptions.CommandError("metadata already exists") for key, value in metadata.items(): if value is None and key in currentmetadata: raise exceptions.CommandError("metadata key %s does not exist" " hence can not be deleted" % userkey)

commit_message:
Provide support for neutron ML2 provider-networks partial specs

Add the option ENABLE_PARTIAL_SPECS to easily enable ML2 provider
networks partial specs feature.

Related to blueprint provider-network-partial-specs

Change-Id: I3a3eef1b108f7f4cfe137e85be134dfc433c2e65
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/46/95546/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Allow to create provider networks using partial specs ENABLE_PARTIAL_SPECS=$(trueorfalse False $ENABLE_PARTIAL_SPECS) if [[ "$ENABLE_PARTIAL_SPECS" = "True" ]]; then iniset /$Q_PLUGIN_CONF_FILE ml2_type_vlan allow_partial_specs True iniset /$Q_PLUGIN_CONF_FILE ml2_type_gre allow_partial_specs True iniset /$Q_PLUGIN_CONF_FILE ml2_type_vxlan allow_partial_specs True fi

commit_message:
Register v3 extensions as v3 extensions

The v3 extensions were registering as public and admin extensions
rather than as v3 extensions.

Change-Id: I369875a9be7229055f51916bb20b0642a18780bc
Related-Bug: #1308252

deleted_lines: extension.register_admin_extension(EXTENSION_DATA['alias'], EXTENSION_DATA) extension.register_public_extension(EXTENSION_DATA['alias'], EXTENSION_DATA)

subject: Copy in keystone paste if platform_family is RHEL
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-06-06 10:20:03.000000000', 'files': ['spec/server-redhat_spec.rb', 'recipes/server.rb'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cookbook-openstack-identity/commit/d880068213f07648c9a21f87cedfda0d43e90860', 'message': 'Copy in keystone paste if platform_family is RHEL

The openstack-keystone package on RHEL does not include
/etc/keystone/keystone-paste.ini, so if we do not manage this file then
just copy it into /etc/keystone from
/usr/share/keystone/keystone-dist-paste.ini.

Change-Id: Ie85701cdae8b7fa93b8fe7d06423c491aafafd88
Closes-Bug: #1327130
'}]
commit_message:
Copy in keystone paste if platform_family is RHEL

The openstack-keystone package on RHEL does not include
/etc/keystone/keystone-paste.ini, so if we do not manage this file then
just copy it into /etc/keystone from
/usr/share/keystone/keystone-dist-paste.ini.

Change-Id: Ie85701cdae8b7fa93b8fe7d06423c491aafafd88
Closes-Bug: #1327130
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cookbook-openstack-identity refs/changes/55/98355/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # If a keystone-paste.ini is specified use it. # If platform_family is RHEL and we do not specify keystone-paste.ini, # copy in /usr/share/keystone/keystone-dist-paste.ini since # /etc/keystone/keystone-paste.ini is not packaged. source node['openstack']['identity']['pastefile_url'] owner node['openstack']['identity']['user'] group node['openstack']['identity']['group'] mode 00644else remote_file '/etc/keystone/keystone-paste.ini' do source 'file:////usr/share/keystone/keystone-dist-paste.ini' action :create_if_missing owner node['openstack']['identity']['user'] group node['openstack']['identity']['group'] mode 00644 notifies :restart, 'service[keystone]', :delayed only_if { platform_family?('rhel') } end
deleted_lines: # If a keystone-paste.ini is specified use it source node['openstack']['identity']['pastefile_url'] owner node['openstack']['identity']['user'] group node['openstack']['identity']['group'] mode 00644

commit_message:
Revert "Fail fast during advanced networking test"

This reverts commit ae3dbdc11fc182109ca07253b0d81183321d7f1c.

Commit ae3dbdc11fc182109ca07253b0d81183321d7f1c was seen as the recent spike for
the "ssh timeout" failures in neutron, as referenced by this bug [1]. With this
revert, we hope to get things moving again while we root cause the other issue.
We will re-submit ae3dbdc11fc182109ca07253b0d81183321d7f1c to continue
debugging as well.

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1323658

Change-Id: Ida6e1d2096673d359ac7a8eaf9ab366e056c56f5

* Favor one-line conditional assignments instead of more verbose
  assignments inside if...else clauses

Change-Id: Iec65be02e13e8ad0fbc657dbb529d5f68ca15e23

commit_message:
Trivial refactors for gettextutils

* Favor one-line conditional assignments instead of more verbose
  assignments inside if...else clauses

* Favor the usage of generators instead of explicit for loops for
  perfomance

Change-Id: Iec65be02e13e8ad0fbc657dbb529d5f68ca15e23
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/85/98385/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: localedir = localedir or os.environ.get(domain.upper() + '_LOCALEDIR') domain = domain or self.domain t = gettext.translation(domain, localedir=self.localedir, fallback=True) return t.gettext if six.PY3 else t.ugettext msgtext = msgtext or Message._translate_msgid(msgid, domain) desired_locale = system_locale[0] if system_locale[0] else 'en_US' translator = lang.gettext if six.PY3 else lang.ugettext params = dict((key, self._copy_param(val)) for key, val in self.params.items()) params.update((key, self._copy_param(val)) for key, val in other.items()) language_list.extend([identifier for identifier in locale_identifiers if find(identifier)]) translated_dict = dict((key, translate(value, desired_locale)) for (key, value) in six.iteritems(args))
deleted_lines: if localedir is None: localedir = os.environ.get(domain.upper() + '_LOCALEDIR') if domain is None: domain = self.domain t = gettext.translation( domain, localedir=self.localedir, fallback=True, ) if six.PY3: return t.gettext return t.ugettext if not msgtext: msgtext = Message._translate_msgid(msgid, domain) if not system_locale[0]: desired_locale = 'en_US' else: desired_locale = system_locale[0] if six.PY3: translator = lang.gettext else: translator = lang.ugettext for key, val in self.params.items(): params[key] = self._copy_param(val) for key, val in other.items(): params[key] = self._copy_param(val) for i in locale_identifiers: if find(i) is not None: language_list.append(i) translated_dict = {} for (k, v) in six.iteritems(args): translated_v = translate(v, desired_locale) translated_dict[k] = translated_v

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-04-30 11:14:12.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/trove/commit/0aaac044115679a3f337e439a848d77476807e63', 'message': 'Refactor taskmanager. Split heat/native/migration code path

Reasons:
- Trove should be able to manage resource provisioning through:
	- nova, cinder, designate etc. (navites);
	- heat. (orchestration).
	- Main reason is to provide harmless migration from the nova to heat,
	  when heat would be cover all required use cases such as
	  provisioning/resizing/network-attributes-management.

Changes:
- Refactoring:
	- dividing actual manager onto navite(nova/cinder/designate/neutron)
 	  and orchestrator(heat);
	- extracting common code into taskmanager/common.py
	- fixing tests;

Change-Id: Ibdab5cb78bc2a83112fe9813b7effd6e0dd0a503

commit_message:
Refactor taskmanager. Split heat/native/migration code path

Reasons:
 - Trove should be able to manage resource provisioning through:
     - nova, cinder, designate etc. (navites);
     - heat. (orchestration).
     - Main reason is to provide harmless migration from the nova to heat,
       when heat would be cover all required use cases such as
       provisioning/resizing/network-attributes-management.

Changes:
 - Refactoring:
   - dividing actual manager onto navite(nova/cinder/designate/neutron)
     and orchestrator(heat);
   - extracting common code into taskmanager/common.py
   - fixing tests;
   - Resize instance for orchestrator added;
   - Resize volume for orchestrator added.
 - tox.ini modified to run all tests for natives or orchestration.

Change-Id: Ibdab5cb78bc2a83112fe9813b7effd6e0dd0a503
Implements: blueprint resource-manager-interface

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import trove.common.cfg as cfg from trove.common import exception from trove.taskmanager import common from trove.taskmanager import models from trove.taskmanager.resources import base RPC_API_VERSION = base.RPC_API_VERSION CONF = cfg.CONF ENGINE = "native" class Native(base.BaseManager): def __init__(self): super(Native, self).__init__() def resize_volume(self, context, instance_id, new_size): instance_tasks = models.NativeBuiltInstanceTasks.load( context, instance_id) instance_tasks.resize_volume(new_size) def resize_flavor(self, context, instance_id, old_flavor, new_flavor): instance_tasks = models.NativeBuiltInstanceTasks.load( context, instance_id) instance_tasks.resize_flavor(old_flavor, new_flavor) def delete_instance(self, context, instance_id): try: instance_tasks = models.NativeBuiltInstanceTasks.load( context, instance_id) instance_tasks.delete_async() except exception.UnprocessableEntity: instance_tasks = common.FreshInstanceTaskMixin.load( context, instance_id) instance_tasks.delete_async() def create_instance(self, context, instance_id, name, flavor, image_id, databases, users, datastore_manager, packages, volume_size, backup_id, availability_zone, root_password, nics, overrides): instance_tasks = models.NativeFreshInstanceTasks.load( context, instance_id) instance_tasks.update_db(provisioning_engine=ENGINE) instance_tasks.create_instance( flavor, image_id, databases, users, datastore_manager, packages, volume_size, backup_id, availability_zone, root_password, nics, overrides )

commit_message:
Symlink init-keystone into scripts, and use it

os-cloud-config now includes an init-keystone script, replacing the
one shipping in this repository. To make use of it, symlink it into
scripts so it's in the PATH and update the calls to use the new
options, as well as removing the old shell based script to avoid
confusing git and developers.

Change-Id: Ieb2df5fa1dcc51fd42ffa99c9124d2443efac3bf

commit_message:
Confirm disk re-partitioning before proceeding

Ask for a confirmation before Fuel installation on a drive with
existing partition table.

New kickstart kernel parameter:
  - "forceformat" - (yes/no) defaul is "no". Set to "yes" if you
                    want to format chosen drive automatically.

For example, if you add "installdrive=sda forceformat=yes" to the
kernel parameters line in Grub menu, then "sda" drive will be
formatted automatically and Fuel will be installed on it.

Change-Id: I0dfcb1d461748fe6b0698f125201b730d63e41d4
Closes-bug: #1325068
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-main refs/changes/27/97227/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: forceformat="no"function confirm_format { check_drive="$1" local confirm_format="no" if [[ "$forceformat" == "yes" ]] ; then return 0 fi if parted -s /dev/$check_drive print &>/dev/null ; then echo echo "$check_drive drive contains partition table:" parted -s /dev/$check_drive print echo read -p "Do you confirm full $check_drive drive repartitioning/reformatting? (y/N)" confirm_format if [[ "$confirm_format" == "y" ]] || [[ "$forceformat" == "yes" ]]; then return 0 else return 1 fi else return 0 fi } format_confirmed="no" if [[ "$drive" == "$tgtdrive" ]] && match="yes" ; then if confirm_format $tgtdrive ; then format_confirmed="yes" break else tgtdrive="undefined" fi fiif [ "$format_confirmed" != "yes" ] ; then chvt 3 if ! confirm_format $tgtdrive ; then clear echo echo '********************************************************************' echo '* E R R O R *' echo '* *' echo '* Your $tgtdrive disk already has partitions and repartitioning *' echo '* has been cancelled. Installation cannot continue. *' echo '* *' echo '********************************************************************' echo read -p "Press Enter to restart: " _ reboot fi chvt 1 fi
deleted_lines: [[ "$drive" == "$tgtdrive" ]] && match="yes" && break

commit_message:
Add stack_id to base instance model

Reasons:
 - saving stack id would give to trove an
   ability to perform actions such as
   stack update/delete;

Changes:
 - adding stack_id column into base schema;
 - DBInstance model update.

Change-Id: I9c8e44b89df344952185847b6f0824c4f85eba21
Implements: blueprint stack-id

commit_message:
Update stdlib to 4.2.1

Cleanup and merge with our current version 3.2.0
- Sync network manifest with upstream to put dnsmasq-utils to network settings

Implements: blueprint merge-openstack-puppet-modules

Change-Id: I2602614bfb0624f1977757937411162b27720725

commit_message:
Revert "add sink support to designate devstack"

I believe this commit is causing the OpenStack-CI DevStack jobs to fail. If the jobs pass for this review, we'll need to revisit this patch.

This reverts commit fd0d71e7057efb04a9bd5b9a589dad83f5151330.

Change-Id: I23f2f5acb0be914d963904d4c30f54208be3bc8b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/designate refs/changes/93/98093/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: designate server-create --name ns1.devstack.org.
deleted_lines: # wait this many seconds after doing start_designate before trying # to do any client operations DESIGNATE_SERVERS_START_WAIT=${DESIGNATE_SERVERS_START_WAIT:-5} # can have separate domains for fixed and floating ip addresses DESIGNATE_TEST_DOMAIN_FIX=${DESIGNATE_TEST_DOMAIN_FIX:-fix.devstack.org.} DESIGNATE_TEST_EMAIL_FIX=${DESIGNATE_TEST_EMAIL_FIX:-$(echo $DESIGNATE_TEST_DOMAIN_FIX | sed 's/^\(.*\)\.$/admin@\1/')} DESIGNATE_TEST_DOMAIN_FLT=${DESIGNATE_TEST_DOMAIN_FLT:-flt.devstack.org.} DESIGNATE_TEST_EMAIL_FLT=${DESIGNATE_TEST_EMAIL_FLT:-$(echo $DESIGNATE_TEST_DOMAIN_FLT | sed 's/^\(.*\)\.$/admin@\1/')} DESIGNATE_TEST_NSREC=${DESIGNATE_TEST_NSREC:-ns1.devstack.org} if is_service_enabled designate-sink; then if is_service_enabled nova && test -n "$DESIGNATE_TEST_DOMAIN_FIX"; then handlers=nova_fixed # after everything is running, create a test domain, store the domain in the # designate.conf, and restart sink iniset $DESIGNATE_CONF handler:nova_fixed domain_id SETME # make sure this corresponds with notification_topics in nova.conf # nova uses notifications by default iniset $DESIGNATE_CONF handler:nova_fixed notification_topics notifications iniset $DESIGNATE_CONF handler:nova_fixed control_exchange nova # octetN is from the IP address of the new machine iniset $DESIGNATE_CONF handler:nova_fixed format '%(octet0)s-%(octet1)s-%(octet2)s-%(octet3)s.%(domain)s' # devstack only configures nova notifications if ceilometer is used, so # we need to do it here otherwise if ! is_service_enabled ceilometer; then # must set a notification_driver or nova will not issue events iniset $NOVA_CONF DEFAULT notification_driver messaging # by default it will use topic "notification" # set notification_topics to change this fi fi if is_service_enabled neutron && test -n "$DESIGNATE_TEST_DOMAIN_FLT"; then if [[ -n "$handlers" ]]; then handlers=${handlers}"," fi handlers=${handlers}neutron_floatingip # after everything is running, create a test domain, store the domain in the # designate.conf, and restart sink iniset $DESIGNATE_CONF handler:neutron_floatingip domain_id SETME # make sure this corresponds with notification_topics in nova.conf # nova uses notifications by default iniset $DESIGNATE_CONF handler:neutron_floatingip notification_topics notifications iniset $DESIGNATE_CONF handler:neutron_floatingip control_exchange neutron # octetN is from the IP address of the new machine iniset $DESIGNATE_CONF handler:neutron_floatingip format '%(octet0)s-%(octet1)s-%(octet2)s-%(octet3)s.%(domain)s' # devstack only configures nova notifications if ceilometer is used, so # we need to do it here otherwise if ! is_service_enabled ceilometer; then # must set a notification_driver or nova will not issue events iniset $NEUTRON_CONF DEFAULT notification_driver messaging # by default it will use topic "notification" # set notification_topics to change this fi fi iniset $DESIGNATE_CONF service:sink enabled_notification_handlers $handlers fi # get the domain_id given the name function get_domain_id() { designate domain-list | grep "$1" | get_field 1 } # get the domain_name given the id function get_domain_name() { designate domain-list | grep "$1" | get_field 2 } # if the given domain does not exist, it will be created # the domain_id of the domain will be returned function get_or_create_domain_id() { domainid=$(get_domain_id "$1") if [[ -z "$domainid" ]]; then # the 1>&2 will redirect stdout to stderr instead, which is useful # if there are problems, but we don't want the stdout being returned # by this function if [[ "$1" = "$DESIGNATE_TEST_DOMAIN_FIX" ]]; then designate domain-create --name $DESIGNATE_TEST_DOMAIN_FIX --email $DESIGNATE_TEST_EMAIL_FIX --ttl 86400 --description "fixed ip domain" 1>&2 elif [[ "$1" = "$DESIGNATE_TEST_DOMAIN_FLT" ]]; then designate domain-create --name $DESIGNATE_TEST_DOMAIN_FLT --email $DESIGNATE_TEST_EMAIL_FLT --ttl 86400 --description "floating ip domain" 1>&2 else designate domain-create --name $1 --email admin@devstack.org --ttl 86400 --description "domain for $1" 1>&2 fi domainid=$(designate domain-list | grep "$1" | get_field 1) fi echo $domainid } designate server-create --name $DESIGNATE_TEST_NSREC # we can't start sink until we have all of the configuration, including # a domain id of a domain # we can't create the domain until we have a server if is_service_enabled designate-sink; then if is_service_enabled nova && test -n "$DESIGNATE_TEST_DOMAIN_FIX"; then domainid=$(get_or_create_domain_id $DESIGNATE_TEST_DOMAIN_FIX) iniset $DESIGNATE_CONF handler:nova_fixed domain_id $domainid fi if is_service_enabled neutron && test -n "$DESIGNATE_TEST_DOMAIN_FLT"; then domainid=$(get_or_create_domain_id $DESIGNATE_TEST_DOMAIN_FLT) iniset $DESIGNATE_CONF handler:neutron_floatingip domain_id $domainid fi # restart everything stop_designate start_designate fi if [[ -n "$DESIGNATE_SERVERS_START_WAIT" ]]; then sleep $DESIGNATE_SERVERS_START_WAIT # allow designate services to start fi

commit_message:
Remove override of standard angular markup

The angular integration into horizon overode the default content tag {{ }}
since if conflicts with the Django template tag.
The problem is that some angular components (ng-grid) cannot be reused
because they assume the default setting.

Ideally angular code should run unchanged whether run inside of horizon
or outside. This change removes the override. There were no templates that
used the overridden tag.

Closes-bug: #1309642
Change-Id: I9251436e2757ec0a5db0068d1861f3a8492af7ac

revisions:

Previously because files in the cache were moved and the new/ workspaces
were configured first none of the cached files ended up in old/
workspaces. Make it possible to copy the cache the first time around so
that the second time through we can do the mv and get all of the files.

Change-Id: I4f41e3ebbde85a27515c5bd27f6a4c706ffe9bb4
'}]
commit_message:
Put cached files in old/ dirs too

Previously because files in the cache were moved and the new/ workspaces
were configured first none of the cached files ended up in old/
workspaces. Make it possible to copy the cache the first time around so
that the second time through we can do the mv and get all of the files.

Change-Id: I4f41e3ebbde85a27515c5bd27f6a4c706ffe9bb4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate refs/changes/65/98265/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: local copy_cache=$3 if [ -n "$copy_cache" ] ; then # The vm template update job should cache some images in ~/cache. # Move them to where devstack expects: find ~/cache/files/ -mindepth 1 -maxdepth 1 -exec cp {} $DEST/devstack/files/ \; else # The vm template update job should cache some images in ~/cache. # Move them to where devstack expects: find ~/cache/files/ -mindepth 1 -maxdepth 1 -exec mv {} $DEST/devstack/files/ \; fi
deleted_lines: # The vm template update job should cache some images in ~/cache. # Move them to where devstack expects: find ~/cache/files/ -mindepth 1 -maxdepth 1 -exec mv {} $DEST/devstack/files/ \;

commit_message:
remove token from notifier middleware

notifier middleware is capturing token and sending it to MQ. this
is not advisable so we should filter it out.

Change-Id: Ia1bfa1bd24989681db1d2f385defc12e69a01f8d
Closes-Bug: #1321080

commit_message:
add pid directory deletion in murano setup script

Currently when murano is uninstalled from system, the pid directory is not
removed, and it causes problems with reinstalling, because the owner of the
pid directory is no more exists in system due to deletion while uninstalling.
This fact prevents murano-api and engine from starting.

Change-Id: I88aac5e61445538807acc92b31c56ee1fcb023d6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano refs/changes/56/98056/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: rm -rf "/var/run/murano" || retval=$?

commit_message:
make get-pip.py download failures more clear

curl dying ends up being a really unclear failure condition, and
hard to fingerprint in the gate. We should make this much more
explicit when we die.

Also, don't trust the upstream filename, because all the rest of
our logic would break if it changes anyway.

(cherry pick of Ibc2a96b33471d24c597af0d7af896fb10523156f
because our file handling was wrong, and might as well make this
line up with what we're going to land in icehouse / master)

Change-Id: If176e3eabd131e0697c6a67211b7d182ca8045dd

4.1.1 Fix for deploy simple savanna

Patch includes:

ostf test invocation

* Increase timeout to 1200 s for savanna test

* Add timeout parameter to the run single
ostf test method

subject: Simplify creation/cleanup of testenvs
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-05-08 00:35:33.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-incubator/commit/f6dfcfee5210754b50c83dc35f649dc6aab33fc4', 'message': 'Simplify creation/cleanup of testenvs

In I1b10abda0209f1c58c6c2612542d8a6cd42628e8, the way cleanup-env had to
second-guess what testenv might have done (and even then, couldn't
guarantee that it made the right choice and had to accept an explicit
override for the seed VM's name) caused a significant amount of
confusion.

Thinking about this overnight, I came to believe that the cause of this
confusion is the fact that two unrelated parameters to
devtest_testenv.sh are being entangled in the choice of name for the
seed_vm. Many people who looked at cleanup-env made the assumption that
if "-n N" is passed to _testenv.sh, the seed name will be seed_N.

This seems to me as though it's a reasonable assumption, and tweaking
the code to behave this way makes it simpler.

To the best of my knowledge, the -n and -b options were added to
_testenv to support CI, which always uses them together. This change
should make no difference to CI.

This change *may* affect people who previously used -n without -b, but
as I don't see how they'd have a working setup with >1 environments all
competing for the single VM named "seed", I don't believe this is a
problem.

Change-Id: I3a0d4315aa3e7d5281db827f01b681d7d8c3128d

commit_message:
Simplify creation/cleanup of testenvs

In I1b10abda0209f1c58c6c2612542d8a6cd42628e8, the way cleanup-env had to
second-guess what testenv might have done (and even then, couldn't
guarantee that it made the right choice and had to accept an explicit
override for the seed VM's name) caused a significant amount of
confusion.

Thinking about this overnight, I came to believe that the cause of this
confusion is the fact that two unrelated parameters to
devtest_testenv.sh are being entangled in the choice of name for the
seed_vm. Many people who looked at cleanup-env made the assumption that
if "-n N" is passed to _testenv.sh, the seed name will be seed_N.

This seems to me as though it's a reasonable assumption, and tweaking
the code to behave this way makes it simpler.

To the best of my knowledge, the -n and -b options were added to
_testenv to support CI, which always uses them together. This change
should make no difference to CI.

This change *may* affect people who previously used -n without -b, but
as I don't see how they'd have a working setup with >1 environments all
competing for the single VM named "seed", I don't believe this is a
problem.

Change-Id: I3a0d4315aa3e7d5281db827f01b681d7d8c3128d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-incubator refs/changes/34/92734/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: SEED_NAME=seed BRIDGE_NAME= SEED_NAME="seed_${NUM}"
deleted_lines: echo " -o seed_name -- Name of the seed to clean up." echo " If not provided, seed_n will be assumed" echo " if -n is used; or simply seed if -n is" echo " not provided. " SEED_NAME="${SEED_NAME:-seed_${NUM}}"SEED_NAME="${SEED_NAME:-seed}"

commit_message:
Add OpenStack upgrader to fuel-upgrade

OpenStack upgrader performs the following tasks:

* add information about new releases to Nailgun
* add notification about new releases to Nailgun

Related to blueprint fuel-upgrade
Change-Id: I962921492e09e06eb0396fae26c4bea1774720df
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web refs/changes/26/87326/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from fuel_upgrade.upgrade import OpenStackUpgrader from fuel_upgrade.upgrade import UpgradeManager #: A dict with supported systems. #: The key is used for system option in CLI. SUPPORTED_SYSTEMS = { 'docker': DockerUpgrader, 'openstack': OpenStackUpgrader, } parser = argparse.ArgumentParser( description='fuel-upgrade is an upgrade system for fuel-master node') 'systems', choices=SUPPORTED_SYSTEMS.keys(), nargs='+', help='systems to upgrade') '--source', required=True, help='path to folder with update files') parser.add_argument( '--no-rollback', help='do not rollback in case of errors', action='store_true') # create a list of upgraders to be use upgraders = [ SUPPORTED_SYSTEMS[system] for system in args.systems ] upgrade_manager = UpgradeManager( args.source, upgraders, not args.no_rollback ) upgrade_manager.run()
deleted_lines: from fuel_upgrade.upgrade import Upgrade parser = argparse.ArgumentParser() '--src', help='path to update file', required=True) '--disable_rollback', help='disable rollabck in case of errors', action='store_false') upgrader = Upgrade( args.src, DockerUpgrader(args.src), disable_rollback=args.disable_rollback) upgrader.run()

make use of is_xml()

calls is_xml where appropriate.

commit_message:
Use six.add_metaclass instead of __metaclass__

According to http://docs.openstack.org/developer/hacking/ it should
be preferred to use six.add_metaclass instead of __metaclass__.

Added new requirement six >= 1.6.0.

Change-Id: Ic7e4f5cb03889cc6bfdb04a657d4654b5fedc985

commit_message:
Use distinct names to create Heat stacks

A Heat stack name will be in the format of:
[assembly name]-[assembly uuid]

Closes-Bug: #1316304

Change-Id: I55136937def95f016917f50df1b3bff75ccfee16

commit_message:
Add YAML format support for Plan resource by using Pecan

Closes-Bug: #1324931
Change-Id: If060bb39761831c2790c7d847a0fd02de5ae2d25
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/solum refs/changes/04/96804/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import yaml @exception.wrap_pecan_controller_exception @pecan.expose(content_type='application/x-yaml') plan_yml = yaml.dump(handler.get(self._id).refined_content()) pecan.response.status = 200 return plan_yml @exception.wrap_pecan_controller_exception @pecan.expose(content_type='application/x-yaml') def put(self): if pecan.request.body == '': raise exception.BadRequest input_plan_yml = yaml.load(pecan.request.body) updated_plan_yml = yaml.dump( handler.update(self._id, input_plan_yml).refined_content()) pecan.response.status = 200 return updated_plan_yml @exception.wrap_wsme_controller_exception handler.delete(self._id) @exception.wrap_pecan_controller_exception @pecan.expose(content_type='application/x-yaml') def post(self): if pecan.request.body == '': raise exception.BadRequest input_plan = yaml.load(pecan.request.body) create_plan_yml = yaml.dump(handler.create(input_plan). refined_content()) pecan.response.status = 201 return create_plan_yml @exception.wrap_pecan_controller_exception @pecan.expose(content_type='application/x-yaml') plan_yml = yaml.dump([obj.refined_content() for obj in handler.get_all() if obj and obj.raw_content]) pecan.response.status = 200 return plan_yml
deleted_lines: from solum.api.controllers.v1.datamodel import planfrom solum import objects @exception.wrap_controller_exception @wsme_pecan.wsexpose(plan.Plan) return plan.Plan.from_db_model(handler.get(self._id), pecan.request.host_url) @exception.wrap_controller_exception @wsme_pecan.wsexpose(plan.Plan, body=plan.Plan) def put(self, data): res = handler.update(self._id, data.as_dict(objects.registry.Plan)) return plan.Plan.from_db_model(res, pecan.request.host_url) @exception.wrap_controller_exception return handler.delete(self._id) @exception.wrap_controller_exception @wsme_pecan.wsexpose(plan.Plan, body=plan.Plan, status_code=201) def post(self, data): return plan.Plan.from_db_model( handler.create(data.as_dict(objects.registry.Plan)), pecan.request.host_url) @exception.wrap_controller_exception @wsme_pecan.wsexpose([plan.Plan]) return [plan.Plan.from_db_model(obj, pecan.request.host_url) for obj in handler.get_all()]

commit_message:
remove redundant check from find_affected_books

The current code checks first if cfg.CONF.only_book is _not_ defined
and immediately after that, whether cfg.CONF.only_book _is_ defined
before it uses that list.

This patch removes the second, redundant check.

Change-Id: I701f530efff9c13b098d9f9b974c8d0eb6aabcb7

commit_message:
Creates jenkins job for automated tests for Engine

Creates Jenkins job which will allow to run all automated tests
for Murano Engine, which will test deployment of all existing
applications on internal CI lab.
These tests will allow to validate that new changes doesn't
break some basic functionality in Murano components.

Change-Id: Ic5f29432d5cde565ad04e80c0da1dd1daf469546
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano-deployment refs/changes/13/97913/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: function prepare_incubator_at() { local retval=0 local git_url="https://github.com/murano-project/murano-app-incubator" local start_dir=$1 local clone_dir="${start_dir}/murano-app-incubator" $GIT_CMD clone $git_url $clone_dir if [ $? -ne 0 ]; then echo "Error occured during git clone $git_url $clone_dir!" retval=1 else cd $clone_dir local pkg_counter=0 for package_dir in io.murano.* do if [ -d "$package_dir" ]; then if [ -f "${package_dir}/manifest.yaml" ]; then sudo bash make-package.sh $package_dir pkg_counter=$((pkg_counter + 1)) fi fi done cd ${start_dir} if [ $pkg_counter -eq 0 ]; then echo "Warning: $pkg_counter packages was built at $clone_dir!" retval=1 fi fi return $retval } # cd $WORKSPACE/functionaltests prepare_incubator_at $(pwd) || retval=$?

commit_message:
Add source code generation to conf.py

The sourcecode index was not generated previously for oslo-incubator.
This patch adds the code snippet, which generates autoindex for the
docstrings in each of the source files i nthe openstack folder. The
code snippet is based on the one that is used for Ceilometer.

The index.rst is modified to contain the correct autoindex reference.

The tox.ini was also updated with a 'docs' section.

Change-Id: I0afe2712246e4735e9ad97dd4bc2f98cd7d85613

commit_message:
Tolerant behavior in case of RabbitMQ connection problem

- do not requeue task if we have problem with RabbitMQ;
- prevent throttle if only one worker exist.

Notice: after this change Nailgun will not fail task if
Astute perform unexpected exit because we do not requeue
task. In this case we will again see dangling deploy
instead of incorrect error.

Special thanks to Evgeniy L for help.
Backport from 5.0

Change-Id: Ic2e771a6133eb0f95e478417f30c1398647c2597
Closes-Bug: #1316761
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web refs/changes/32/98332/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if @main_work_thread.nil? || !@main_work_thread.alive? Naily.logger.debug "Process message from worker queue: #{payload.inspect}" perform_main_job(metadata, payload) else Naily.logger.debug "Requeue message because worker is busy: #{payload.inspect}" # Avoid throttle by consume/reject cycle if only one worker is running EM.add_timer(2) { metadata.reject(:requeue => true) } end metadata.ack data = parse_data(payload) @tasks_queue = TaskQueue.new @tasks_queue.add_task(data) dispatch(@tasks_queue)
deleted_lines: Naily.logger.debug "Process message from worker queue: #{payload.inspect}" perform_main_job(metadata, payload) begin data = parse_data(payload) @tasks_queue = TaskQueue.new @tasks_queue.add_task(data) dispatch(@tasks_queue) ensure metadata.ack end

subject: is_xml{,_like} handle paths, not filenames
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-06-05 17:02:15.000000000', 'files': ['os_doc_tools/doctest.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-doc-tools/commit/53b97a1f6fe9d7fbccfa910fbb9a62ca25203cf3', 'message': 'is_xml{,_like} handle paths, not filenames

The way is_xml and is_xml_like handle the pom.xml case, one seems to
expect a filename while the other expects a path.

This patch makes both functions more robust so they can handle both
path and filename, but won't incorrectly filter filenames that only
happen to end on "pom.xml" (say, fun-with-a-pompom.xml).

Change-Id: Id2653152b2e46bfa9b892a8f656cccaa44a8185a
'}]
commit_message:
is_xml{,_like} handle paths, not filenames

The way is_xml and is_xml_like handle the pom.xml case, one seems to
expect a filename while the other expects a path.

This patch makes both functions more robust so they can handle both
path and filename, but won't incorrectly filter filenames that only
happen to end on "pom.xml" (say, fun-with-a-pompom.xml).

Change-Id: Id2653152b2e46bfa9b892a8f656cccaa44a8185a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-doc-tools refs/changes/76/98176/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def is_xml(path): filename = os.path.basename(path) return filename.endswith('.xml') and not filename == 'pom.xml' def is_xml_like(path): filename = os.path.basename(path) not filename == 'pom.xml')
deleted_lines: def is_xml(filename): return filename.endswith('.xml') and not filename.endswith('/pom.xml') def is_xml_like(filename): not filename.endswith('pom.xml'))

commit_message:
Update contrib/ci  bash scripts

Actions from setup.sh files are supposed
to be moved to job itself. All changes needed only for tempest
are stored in post_test_hook.

So, no need to keep these files.
When files from multi_backend become not used, they
should be removed too.

Change-Id: I3da41e2843de3e2dfaf4952aea5f7e00a6ff9940

commit_message:
Use getLogger(__name__)

The variable __name__ should be preferred over hardcoded names
to reference the used logging object.

Change-Id: I366afd3e9368eee5ca17f3b351575ca043693e2d

commit_message:
Add API test for resizing a stopped server

The compute API allows resizing a stopped server but we don't test it
and we've regressed that flow in the past, so add a test to guard
against it.

Change-Id: I6ca84da9deb9b9a97fad0e68b5f0845a617ae314
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/12/87312/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _test_resize_server_confirm(self, stop=False): if stop: resp, server = self.servers_client.stop(self.server_id) self.assertEqual(202, resp.status) self.servers_client.wait_for_server_status(self.server_id, 'SHUTOFF') @test.attr(type='smoke') def test_resize_server_confirm(self): self._test_resize_server_confirm(stop=False) @testtools.skipUnless(CONF.compute_feature_enabled.resize, 'Resize not available.') @test.attr(type='smoke') def test_resize_server_confirm_from_stopped(self): self._test_resize_server_confirm(stop=True) @testtools.skipUnless(CONF.compute_feature_enabled.resize, 'Resize not available.')
deleted_lines: @testtools.skipUnless(CONF.compute_feature_enabled.resize, 'Resize not available.') @test.attr(type='smoke') def test_resize_server_confirm(self):

subject: Record and log reason for dhcp agent resync
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-03-18 05:20:07.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/1ef7cc13f495825334462d2cce35823ab61e25a6', 'message': 'Record and log reason for dhcp agent resync

A dhcp resync can be triggered at a number of points, but the actual
resync is done asynchronously by a helper thread.  This means by the
time the resync happens, it's hard to establish what actually caused
it.

I've seen a number of problems in production systems that cause
excessive resyncs.  One is a ipv6/dnsmasq issue (rhbz#1077487) and
another is db corruption with duplicate entries [1].  The resync
triggers a whole lot of logs itself, so it becomes very unclear how to
establish any causaility.

What I propose is to keep track of what triggered the resync with some
helpful information.  We add a schedule_resync() function to track
this and log the output when the resync happens.

[1] The logs will contain output like "DBDuplicateEntry
(IntegrityError) (1062, "Duplicate entry
'6d799c6a-7a09-4c1e-bb63-7d30fd052c8a-d3e3ac5b-9962-428a-a9f8-6b2' for
key 'PRIMARY'") ..." in this case

Change-Id: I9b1c6202f5a6bbad8589a8b64b2a38c9d9edb43b

commit_message:
Record and log reason for dhcp agent resync

A dhcp resync can be triggered at a number of points, but the actual
resync is done asynchronously by a helper thread.  This means by the
time the resync happens, it's hard to establish what actually caused
it.

There have been a number of problems in production systems that cause
excessive resyncs.  One is a ipv6/dnsmasq issue (rhbz#1077487) and
another is db corruption with duplicate entries [1].  The resync
triggers a whole lot of logs itself, so it becomes very unclear how to
establish any causality.

This change keeps track of what triggered the resync with some helpful
information.  We add a schedule_resync() function to to replace a
explicit set of needs_resync which tracks why it was called.

[1] The logs will contain output like "DBDuplicateEntry
(IntegrityError) (1062, "Duplicate entry
'6d799c6a-7a09-4c1e-bb63-7d30fd052c8a-d3e3ac5b-9962-428a-a9f8-6b2' for
key 'PRIMARY'") ..." in this case

Closes-Bug: #1294445
Change-Id: I9b1c6202f5a6bbad8589a8b64b2a38c9d9edb43b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/73/81173/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.needs_resync_reasons = [] self.schedule_resync(e) def schedule_resync(self, reason): """Schedule a resync for a given reason.""" self.needs_resync = True self.needs_resync_reasons.append(reason) except Exception as e: self.schedule_resync(e) except Exception as e: self.schedule_resync(e) LOG.debug(_("Synchronize state : %(reasons)s"), {"reasons": self.needs_resync_reasons}) self.needs_resync_reasons = [] except Exception as e: self.schedule_resync(e) self.schedule_resync(_("Agent updated %(payload)s"), {"payload": payload})
deleted_lines: self.needs_resync = True except Exception: self.needs_resync = True except Exception: self.needs_resync = True except Exception: self.needs_resync = True self.needs_resync = True

commit_message:
Improve help text for commands.py

If no arguments are given, print the whole help text. Since the list of
supported commands is hard-coded, provide that list in the help text.

Change-Id: Icc6a606b435b02cec151cb606e4ef94754b1c53d

commit_message:
commands.py: handle missing command

The current code aborts with a traceback if the command meant to be
documented is missing. This patch makes the program handle that case
more gracefully.

Change-Id: Id767bcf5731339d219b6b05af27fbe7722881591
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-doc-tools refs/changes/28/98328/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: try: version = check_output([os_command, "--version"], stderr=subprocess.STDOUT) except OSError as e: if e.errno == os.errno.ENOENT: print("Command %s not found, aborting." % os_command) sys.exit(1)
deleted_lines: version = check_output([os_command, "--version"], stderr=subprocess.STDOUT)

commit_message:
Wrong order of attributes in assertEqual

As a part of fix of bug 1277104 -
In response validation, during check using assertEqual,
correct order of attributes are assertEqual(<expected>, <actual>).
But in this case it was (actual, expected).
This patch corrects this order for baremetal API tests.

part of blueprint: missing-baremetal-api-test

Change-Id: I0f831150aa2b68adae789551c0ab487244724519

deleted_lines: self.assertEqual(resp['status'], '204')

commit_message:
Allow user-specified timeout for stack creation

The 60 min. timeout on stack creation is not sufficient for provisioning
a large number of nodes.  This allows the timeout for both undercloud and
overcloud stacks to be specified via environment varibles.  Both stacks
are created in Heat with a 6 hour timeout, and we rely entirely on
wait_for_stack_ready() to enforce the client-side timeout.  The default
remains 60 min.

Change-Id: I49ad0a6035392269d45b13a16fe0a78a61b38dfd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-incubator refs/changes/68/95968/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # A client-side timeout in minutes for creating or updating the overcloud # Heat stack. OVERCLOUD_STACK_TIMEOUT=${OVERCLOUD_STACK_TIMEOUT:-360} # create stack with a 6 hour timeout, and allow wait_for_stack_ready # to impose a realistic timeout. -t 360 \wait_for_stack_ready $(($OVERCLOUD_STACK_TIMEOUT * 60 / 10)) 10 $STACKNAME
deleted_lines: # Make time out 60 mins as like the Heat stack-create default timeout. wait_for_stack_ready 360 10 $STACKNAME

subject: Get info for volume backed snapshot from an instance.
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-05-26 13:41:54.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/2e406d0a21db885a48890e97dc39916de4953b89', 'message': "Get info for volume backed snapshot from an instance.

Current implementation of creating snapshot from a volume
backed instance has some weakness.

1 In instance booted from image case it uses the image info as
the template to create a new image. But original image contains
many attributes and possibly properties are harmful or not
needed for the new image. For example id, checksum.
Current implementation has to clean harmful attributes instead
of to explicity set significant ones. Also it transfer
not needed attributes to the new image, in the result
the last one looks oddly.

2 In instance booted from volume case it uses image metadata
stored in the volume. But unlike original image info
this metadata stores image attributes not hierarchically.
Since no transformation is provided, some critical attributes
are handled as image properties and are lost.
For example disk_format. In the result we have bad image with
many oddly properties.

3 Public method of Nova Compute API cann't create snapshot
unless appropriate image metadata is provided to it. But this
is not consistently. For example we cann't create a raw snapshot
from an ami instance. A caller should prepare image meta by
instance info, and then API method prepares a rest of image meta
by instance info as well.
In theory the public method should make a snapshot of
an instance, gathering all sufficient instance dependend info by
itself.

When current implementation was first introduced
(Essex milestone, EC2 layer), no other soures of image meta
existed. But later instance system metadata was founded, and now
it keeps all original image metadata is needed to create
a snapshot. This metadata is copied from an image or from image
metadata stored in a boot volume.

In this changeset only instance system metadata is used
to create a volume backed instance snapshot.

Change-Id: I7106ec0dd26ccede276da7945362677d00e5e33c
Closes-Bug: #1322157
Related-Bug: #1322195

commit_message:
Get info for volume backed snapshot from an instance.

Current implementation of creating snapshot from a volume
backed instance has some weakness.

1 In instance booted from image case it uses the image info as
the template to create a new image. But original image contains
many attributes and possibly properties are harmful or not
needed for the new image. For example id, checksum.
Current implementation has to clean harmful attributes instead
of to explicity set significant ones. Also it transfer
not needed attributes to the new image, in the result
the last one looks oddly.

2 In instance booted from volume case it uses image metadata
stored in the volume. But unlike original image info
this metadata stores image attributes not hierarchically.
Since no transformation is provided, some critical attributes
are handled as image properties and are lost.
For example disk_format. In the result we have bad image with
many oddly properties.

3 Public method of Nova Compute API cann't create snapshot
unless appropriate image metadata is provided to it. But this
is not consistently. For example we cann't create a raw snapshot
from an ami instance. A caller should prepare image meta by
instance info, and then API method prepares a rest of image meta
by instance info as well.
In theory the public method should make a snapshot of
an instance, gathering all sufficient instance dependend info by
itself.

When current implementation was first introduced
(Essex milestone, EC2 layer), no other soures of image meta
existed. But later instance system metadata was founded, and now
it keeps all original image metadata is needed to create
a snapshot. This metadata is copied from an image or from image
metadata stored in a boot volume.

In this changeset only instance system metadata is used
to create a volume backed instance snapshot.

Change-Id: I7106ec0dd26ccede276da7945362677d00e5e33c
Closes-Bug: #1322157
Related-Bug: #1322195

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-06-05 06:07:36.000000000', 'files': ['doc/install-guide/app_reserved_uids.xml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals/commit/fd1f151a4664b5488e14ccf685d9055fd89d7963', 'message': 'Add UID of Trove assigned during installation (F20/EL6/EL7)

Latest SPECs are available at
http://repos.fedorapeople.org/repos/openstack/openstack-icehouse/.

---snip---
getent passwd $USERNAME >/dev/null || \
  useradd -r -g $GROUPNAME -G $GROUPNAME -d $HOMEDIR -s /sbin/nologin \

---snap---

commit_message:
Add UID of Trove assigned during installation (F20/EL6/EL7)

According to the latest SPECs used for F20/EL6/EL7 there is no
specific UID used for Trove.

Latest SPECs are available at
http://repos.fedorapeople.org/repos/openstack/openstack-icehouse/.

---snip---
getent passwd $USERNAME >/dev/null || \
  useradd -r -g $GROUPNAME -G $GROUPNAME -d $HOMEDIR -s /sbin/nologin \
    -c "$USERNAME Daemons" $USERNAME
---snap---

Change-Id: I651979d76f25692d30a8447d9e1a16ef6263696c

Some readability fixup for dbconfig

During the backport of the previous patch, Diane Fleming suggested
some fixes: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/97552/. This patch
applies it to the master branch first.

This is a backport of: https://review.openstack.org/97849

commit_message:
Prepare documentation for readthedocs

Create Makefile and recreate conf.py using sphinx-quickstart
Add _build to gitignore
Fix several nits in rst files
Add tox environment for docs building. Now docs may be built by
running `tox -edoc'

Change-Id: Ib0eb17047e583bdf3ac9111e117f908340f4d5ef

commit_message:
Use FakeCeilometerClient instead of mocks

FakeCeilometerClient can be used instead of mocking ceilometer
client from osclients completely. This patch implements
FakeCeilometerClient and modifies tests for ceilometer components.

blueprint: benchmark-scenarios-for-celiometer
Change-Id: I2fcdb2bc3e1a70a1ff2c05a8939ca1de171bd4c0

added_lines: class FakeAlarm(FakeResource): def __init__(self, manager=None, **kwargs): super(FakeAlarm, self).__init__(manager) class FakeAlarmManager(FakeManager): def __init__(self): super(FakeAlarmManager, self).__init__() def get(self, alarm_id): alarm = self.cache.get(alarm_id, None) if alarm is not None: return alarm raise exc.HTTPNotFound("Alarm with %s not found" % (alarm_id)) def create(self, alarm_id='fake_alarm_id', threshold='fake_threshold', **kwargs): alarm = FakeAlarm(kwargs) alarm.alarm_id = alarm_id alarm.threshold = threshold alarm.optional_args = kwargs.get('optional_args', {}) return self._cache(alarm) self.alarms = FakeAlarmManager() # TODO(Aswad): define Fake*Manager as done for # FakeAlarmManager. # example: # self.resources = FakeCeilometerResourceManager() # self.meters = FakeMetersManager()

added_lines: "POT-Creation-Date: 2014-06-05 21:55+0000\n" "PO-Revision-Date: 2014-06-05 22:30+0000\n""Virtual Networking Infrastructure (VNI) in your OpenStack environment. " "OpenStack Networking also manages the access layer aspects of the Physical " "Networking Infrastructure (PNI). Tenants can create advanced virtual network" " topologies using OpenStack Networking. These topologies include services " "such as <glossterm baseform=\"firewall\">firewalls</glossterm>, <glossterm " "baseform=\"load balancer\">load balancers</glossterm>, and <glossterm " "baseform=\"virtual private network (VPN)\"> virtual private networks " "(VPNs)</glossterm>." msgstr "OpenStack Networking (neutron) は、OpenStack 環境で仮想ネットワークインフラストラクチャ (VNI) のすべてのネットワークファセットを管理します。また、OpenStack Networking は物理ネットワークインフラストラクチャ (PNI) のアクセス層の側面も管理します。プロジェクトが<glossterm baseform=\"firewall\">ファイアウォール</glossterm>、<glossterm baseform=\"load balancer\">負荷分散装置</glossterm>、<glossterm baseform=\"virtual private network (VPN)\">VPN</glossterm> などの高度な仮想ネットワークトポロジーを作成できます。" #: ./doc/install-guide/section_neutron-concepts.xml17(para)"Networking provides the following object abstractions: networks, routers, " "and subnets. Each has a functionality that mimics its physical counterpart: "msgstr "Networking はネットワーク、ルーター、サブネットのオブジェクトの抽象化を提供します。それぞれ、対応する物理的なものの機能を模倣します。ネットワークがサブネットを含みます。ルーターがサブネットやネットワーク間の通信を中継します。" #: ./doc/install-guide/section_neutron-concepts.xml21(para)"Each router has one gateway that connects to a network, and many interfaces " "connected to subnets. Subnets can access machines on other subnets connected" " to the same router." msgstr "各ルーターは、ネットワークに接続する 1 つのゲートウェイ、サブネットに接続する複数のインターフェースを持ちます。サブネットは、同じルーターに接続された他のサブネットにあるマシンにアクセスできます。" #: ./doc/install-guide/section_neutron-concepts.xml24(para) msgid "" "Any given Networking set up has at least one external network. This external" " network, unlike the other networks, is not solely a virtually defined " "network. It instead provides a view into a slice of the network accessible " "outside the OpenStack installation, which is the outside network. IP " "addresses on the external network are accessible by anybody physically on " "the outside network. DHCP is disabled on this network." msgstr "すべての Networking 環境は少なくとも 1 つの外部ネットワークを持ちます。この外部ネットワークは、他のネットワークと異なり、ほとんど仮想的に定義されたネットワークではありません。これは OpenStack インストール環境の外部からアクセス可能なネットワークの一部のビューであることを意味します。これは外部ネットワークです。外部ネットワークの IP アドレスは外部ネットワークにある何らかの物理的なものによりアクセスできます。DHCP はこのネットワークで無効化されます。" #: ./doc/install-guide/section_neutron-concepts.xml31(para) msgid "" "Machines can access the outside network through the gateway for the router. " "For the outside network to access VMs, and for VM's to access the outside " "network, routers between the networks are needed." msgstr "マシンが、ルーターのゲートウェイ経由で外部ネットワークにアクセスできます。外部ネットワークが仮想マシンにアクセスするため、仮想マシンが外部ネットワークにアクセスするために、ネットワーク間のルーターが必要です。" #: ./doc/install-guide/section_neutron-concepts.xml35(para)"connection is called a port.You can associate external network IP addresses " "with ports to VMs. This way, entities on the outside network can access VMs.""groups</emphasis>, which enable administrators to define firewall rules in " "groups. A VM can belong to one or more security groups. Networking applies " "the rules in those security groups to block or unblock ports, port ranges, " "or traffic types for that VM." msgstr "Networking は <emphasis role=\"italic\">セキュリティグループ</emphasis> もサポートします。これにより、管理者がグループでファイアウォールルールを定義できます。仮想マシンは 1 つ以上のセキュリティグループに属します。Networking が、ポート、ポート範囲、または通信種別をブロックするかブロックしないかのために、これらのセキュリティグループにあるルールを仮想マシンに対して適用します。" #: ./doc/install-guide/section_neutron-concepts.xml51(title) msgid "Networking plug-ins" msgstr "Networking プラグイン" #: ./doc/install-guide/section_neutron-concepts.xml52(para)"Each plug-in that Networking uses has its own concepts. These plug-in " "concepts are not vital to operating Networking. Understanding these concepts" " can help you set up the Openstack Networking service, however. All " "Networking installations use a core plug-in and a security group plug-in (or" " just the No-Op security group plug-in). Additionally, Firewall-as-a-service" " (FWaaS) and Load-balancing-as-a-service (LBaaS) plug-ins are available." msgstr "Networking が使用する各プラグインはそれぞれ独自の概念を持ちます。これらのプラグインの概念は、Networking を稼働されるために必須ではありません。しかしながら、これらの概念を理解することにより、Openstack Networking をセットアップする役に立つでしょう。すべての Networking インストール環境は、コアプラグインとセキュリティグループプラグイン (またはただの No-Op セキュリティグループプラグイン) を使用します。さらに、Firewall-as-a-service (FWaaS) と Load-balancing-as-a-service (LBaaS) プラグインが利用可能です。"msgid "Add the Compute services" msgstr "Compute の追加"

subject: Fix InstanceActionEvent traceback parameter not serializable
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-05-09 10:23:39.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/2e096e6f8bd3c6925d705463e4fec1e3177b23ee', 'message': 'Fix InstanceActionEvent traceback parameter not serializable

The change to use InstanceActionEvent in compute.utils.EventReporter
changed the order of how things are done. Before, traceback info were
converted to strings before being sent to the conductor. Now, since
the object method being used remotes itself, the order becomes the
opposite and any captured tracebacks are sent as is, resulting in
errors during messaging.

Change-Id: Ibedddd606b9d25ffbbb2b1b5358cf0aa4741083f
Closes-Bug: #1317804
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-05-16 22:08:53.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/335998972d92c5790362f407d82bcf2d94658028', 'message': 'Fix InstanceActionEvent traceback parameter not serializable

The change to use InstanceActionEvent in compute.utils.EventReporter
changed the order of how things are done. Before, traceback info were
converted to a string before being sent to the conductor. Now, since
the object method being used remotes itself, the order becomes the
opposite and any captured tracebacks are sent as is, resulting in
errors during messaging.

This bug has actually existed in the now used methods forever, the
methods have just not been used up until now. When looking into this
issue, it was uncovered that tests for the entire class was not
running (presumably a mistake). This change updates these tests to be
inline with recent changes and makes sure they actually run.

Closes-Bug: #1317804

The change to use InstanceActionEvent in compute.utils.EventReporter
changed the order of how things are done. Before, traceback info were
converted to a string before being sent to the conductor. Now, since
the object method being used remotes itself, the order becomes the
opposite and any captured tracebacks are sent as is, resulting in
errors during messaging.

This adds a serialize_args decorator for this case, which handles
this specific case for the event_finish_with_failure() classmethod.
A more generic approach is needed, and that will be applied to the
also-affected but currently-unused finish_with_failure() instance
method.

commit_message:
Fix InstanceActionEvent traceback parameter not serializable

The change to use InstanceActionEvent in compute.utils.EventReporter
changed the order of how things are done. Before, traceback info were
converted to a string before being sent to the conductor. Now, since
the object method being used remotes itself, the order becomes the
opposite and any captured tracebacks are sent as is, resulting in
errors during messaging.

This adds a serialize_args decorator for this case, which handles
this specific case for the event_finish_with_failure() classmethod.
A more generic approach is needed, and that will be applied to the
also-affected but currently-unused finish_with_failure() instance
method.

Change-Id: Ibedddd606b9d25ffbbb2b1b5358cf0aa4741083f
Co-Authored-By: Dan Smith <dms@danplanet.com>
Closes-Bug: #1317804
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/17/93017/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: values['message'] = exc_val values['traceback'] = exc_tb
deleted_lines: import traceback values['message'] = str(exc_val) values['traceback'] = ''.join(traceback.format_tb(exc_tb))

commit_message:
Add new 'storage': {'production_ready': True} capability

This capability is needed to be used in the Tempest tests
to have the difference between Icehouse version (where tests
won't pass due to *really* huge running time) and new Juno
version, where this performance issue has been fixed.

Change-Id: I83bf184a58bfba0e48e09a754237a8b0a4dceb25

commit_message:
Fix murano integration tests job

- changed workspace for murano-engine tests job to Murano sources directory
  because now tests are executed from Murano sources
- fix literal errors
- set tests configuration file owner to Jenkins

Change-Id: I958706e7db4adbc861a10d6e4bad353422c5e863

subject: teach get_installed_ovs_klm_version about vermagic:
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-06-05 18:04:14.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/a7293cc0a0d437a33aaaf1b7ba174e9cabe3ba92', 'message': 'teach get_installed_ovs_klm_version about vermagic:

On Fedora 20, neutron-openvswitch-agent fails to start with the
following error:

  neutron.plugins.openvswitch.agent.ovs_neutron_agent SystemError: Unable
  to determine kernel version for Open vSwitch with VXLAN support. To use
  VXLAN tunnels with OVS, please ensure that the version is 1.10 or newer!

In neutron/agent/linux/ovs_lib.py, the code is attempting to determine
the installed version of the openvswitch module by calling:

  modinfo openvswitch

It's looking for a line containing "version: ", but "modinfo" produces
no such line; the output looks like this:

  filename:
  /lib/modules/3.11.10-301.fc20.x86_64/kernel/net/openvswitch/openvswitch.ko
  license: GPL
  description: Open vSwitch switching datapath
  depends: gre
  intree: Y
  vermagic: 3.11.10-301.fc20.x86_64 SMP mod_unload
  signer: Fedora kernel signing key
  sig_key: 03:59:1D:C5:7A:69:07:41:40:1A:1C:20:2E:2B:3D:9F:4F:ED:2A:0E
  sig_hashalgo: sha256

This patch teaches get_installed_ovs_klm_version about the "vermagic: "
line, which also provides the desired information.

Change-Id: I6b84657d58cef09cca9ae3162e3ea2adbef56034

commit_message:
teach get_installed_ovs_klm_version about vermagic:

On Fedora 20, neutron-openvswitch-agent fails to start with the
following error:

  neutron.plugins.openvswitch.agent.ovs_neutron_agent SystemError: Unable
  to determine kernel version for Open vSwitch with VXLAN support. To use
  VXLAN tunnels with OVS, please ensure that the version is 1.10 or newer!

In neutron/agent/linux/ovs_lib.py, the code is attempting to determine
the installed version of the openvswitch module by calling:

  modinfo openvswitch

It's looking for a line containing "version: ", but "modinfo" produces
no such line; the output looks like this:

  filename:
  /lib/modules/3.11.10-301.fc20.x86_64/kernel/net/openvswitch/openvswitch.ko
  license: GPL
  description: Open vSwitch switching datapath
  depends: gre
  intree: Y
  vermagic: 3.11.10-301.fc20.x86_64 SMP mod_unload
  signer: Fedora kernel signing key
  sig_key: 03:59:1D:C5:7A:69:07:41:40:1A:1C:20:2E:2B:3D:9F:4F:ED:2A:0E
  sig_hashalgo: sha256

This patch teaches get_installed_ovs_klm_version about the "vermagic: "
line, which also provides the desired information.

Change-Id: I6b84657d58cef09cca9ae3162e3ea2adbef56034
Closes-bug: #1326907

added_lines: @session_aware() def trigger_delete(trigger_id, session=None): trigger = _trigger_get(trigger_id) if not trigger: raise exc.NotFoundException("Trigger not found [trigger_id=%s]" % trigger_id) session.delete(trigger) trigger = _trigger_get(trigger_id) if not trigger: raise exc.NotFoundException("Trigger not found [trigger_id=%s]" % trigger_id) return trigger execution_list = executions_get_all(workbook_name=workbook_name) for execution in execution_list: execution_delete(workbook_name, execution['id']) trigger_list = triggers_get_all(workbook_name=workbook_name) for trigger in trigger_list: trigger_delete(trigger['id']) task_list = tasks_get_all(workbook_name=workbook_name, execution_id=execution_id) for task in task_list: task_delete(workbook_name, execution_id, task['id']) task = _task_get(workbook_name, execution_id, task_id) if not task: raise exc.NotFoundException( "Task not found [workbook_name=%s, execution_id=%s, task_id=%s]" % (workbook_name, execution_id, task_id)) return task

Add license descriptions to a-z libraries

The dnspython does not show common license, and this patch skips to
discribe it.

commit_message:
Add rfc3987 library

In jsonschema library, it tries to import rfc3987 library for 'uri'
vaildation. And if it fails, jsonschema does not check 'uri' format.
This patch adds rfc3987 to global-requirements.txt to enable 'uri'
check.

Change-Id: Ib7556454b8365aae58452ec1838b877e692e1d68
Related-Bug: #1326599
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/requirements refs/changes/12/98012/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Synced jsonutils from oslo-incubator

The sync includes change that makes sure we get unicode-only dicts from
jsonutils no matter which json module implementation is selected.

The latest commit in oslo-incubator:
- 0f4586c0076183c6356eec682c8a593648125abd

Change-Id: Ic815ca3df94c33edec9104172048b2cd94b92e3f
Closes-Bug: 1314129
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-novaclient refs/changes/98/95698/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import codecsfrom novaclient.openstack.common import strutilsdef loads(s, encoding='utf-8'): return json.loads(strutils.safe_decode(s, encoding)) def load(fp, encoding='utf-8'): return json.load(codecs.getreader(encoding)(fp))
deleted_lines: def loads(s): return json.loads(s) def load(s): return json.load(s)

commit_message:
Added validation for long hostnames

* Sahara checks that composite instance name with maximum id doesn't
  exceed default limit 64 for characters when changing hostnames by command:
  "hostname new-host-name"
* Composite name described in previous point is:
  "cluster_name" + "node_group_name + "instance_id" + "." + "novalocal"
* Applied for cluster creation validation and scailing operation
* Exctracted constructing of composite name to separate utils method

Change-Id: I2dd3724398c10fb1d6dad87606f6123e50f851d5
Closes-Bug: #1300391

commit_message:
Implements filters and schedules in nova.cfg

Adding filters and scheduling parameters to nova.cfg for better to reach
more smooth VM distribution across non-homogeneous compute nodes.

Backport to stable/4.1 includes follow-up fix from:
Idb3dbb6fddb18c06759e483731b971a1be953583.

Change-Id: I59a49c613da29eda04eec7dfe911d8fc31380a33
Implements: blueprint scheduler-config-improvements
Closes-Bug: 1300027

commit_message:
Migrate Ceilometer Python Client to Support Keystone V3 APIs

Keystone is deprecating the V2 APIs and moving to V3 APIs. All the services'
clients are going to add support to V3 in order to smooth the transition.

Change-Id: I95875054b9f771ae89e44a061561472a76c8f4e2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/telemetry-specs refs/changes/70/95270/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================================================ Migrate Ceilometer Python Client to Support Keystone V3 APIs ============================================================ Keystone is deprecating the V2 APIs and moving to V3 APIs. All the services' clients are going to add support to V3 in order to smooth the transition. Problem description =================== Keystone V3 API has introduced the following major changes: * Authentication: Custom auth method can be developed as plug-ins, this enables support for: oauth1 and federation * Authorization: in V2 API therea are only two levels "admin" or none. V3 API enables control of who can call each method if the policy file is correctly specified. * Richer set of APIs. Vendor speific extensions are not supported directly anymore and there is a set of optional extensions supported by Keystone. Proposed change =============== Here is where you cover the change you propose to make in detail. How do you propose to solve this problem? If this is one part of a larger effort make it clear where this piece ends. In other words, what's the scope of this effort? If this larger effort may span several release cycles, state this explicitly. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Pipeline impact --------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- There will be new commands to be used with the ceilometer client to scope the request to Domain/Project and support different auth methods. Performance/Scalability Impacts ------------------------------- None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: fabgia Other contributors: robsparker Ongoing maintainer: fabgia Work Items ---------- * Add new parameters to the client and cli * Call the V3 Keystone client * Validate the authorization and authentication Future lifecycle ================ None Dependencies ============ * Keystone Python Client Testing ======= Unit tests will be added to the Ceilometer client to support the new parameter submission as well as validation of the authorization and authentication with Keystone client. Documentation Impact ==================== Documentation changes specific to new parameters added to the client. References ========== Keystone related blueprints: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/document-v2-to-v3-transition

commit_message:
Make the image name configurable

Remove the hardcoded "user" for the image name.
Remove the hardcoded container type and format.

Change-Id: Id17f3ef8f5b73b4805b29fd1a8d2f23ac7ed0770

commit_message:
Fix usage of oslo.config

- make it possible to create a DBAPI instance given a config instance

- remove usage of global cfg.CONF instance (it's up to a user to pass
  a ConfigOpts instance to oslo.db)

- ensure end applications don't need to import/register/use config
  options directly - instead they pass a config instance to oslo.db
  helpers (EngineFacade.from_config() and DBAPI.from_config() class
  methods)

At the same time, usage of oslo.config remains completely optional as
we provide an API to pass those parameters programatically.

Change-Id: I1a00db7a4200ebdc96f17256ecbad430477e868f

commit_message:
replace string format arguments with function parameters

There are files containing string format arguments inside
logging messages. Using logging function parameters should
be preferred.

Partial-Bug: #1321274

commit_message:
libvirt: split and test finish_migration disk resize

Adds a '_disk_resize' method to help resizing disk
by checking and preparing the disk to be extend with disk.api.
Update finish_migration to use this helper.

Closes-Bug: #1298975
Signed-off-by: Sahid Orentino Ferdjaoui <sahid.ferdjaoui@cloudwatt.com>

Change-Id: Iefe16915a2e657d848629d7e4a4fcf67298f913e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/97/78597/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _disk_resize(self, info, size): """Attempts to resize a disk to size Attempts to resize a disk to size and returns a tuple of the status of the attempt and the format of the disk. Note: Currently only support disk extend. """ fmt = info['type'] if (size and fmt == 'qcow2' and disk.can_resize_image(info['path'], size) and disk.is_image_partitionless(info['path'], use_cow=True)): self._disk_qcow2_to_raw(info) fmt = 'raw' if size: use_cow = fmt == 'qcow2' disk.extend(info['path'], size, use_cow=use_cow) if fmt == 'raw' and CONF.use_cow_images: # back to qcow2 (no backing_file though) so that snapshot # will be available self._disk_raw_to_qcow2(info) self._disk_resize(info, size)
deleted_lines: # If we have a non partitioned image that we can extend # then ensure we're in 'raw' format so we can extend file system. fmt = info['type'] if (size and fmt == 'qcow2' and disk.can_resize_image(info['path'], size) and disk.is_image_partitionless(info['path'], use_cow=True)): self._disk_qcow2_to_raw(info) fmt = 'raw' if size: use_cow = fmt == 'qcow2' disk.extend(info['path'], size, use_cow=use_cow) if fmt == 'raw' and CONF.use_cow_images: # back to qcow2 (no backing_file though) so that snapshot # will be available self._disk_raw_to_qcow2(info)

heading to review the Neutron Concept section.

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/94/97394/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <para>OpenStack Networking (neutron) manages all of the networking facets for the Virtual Networking Infrastructure (VNI)in your OpenStack environment. OpenStack Networking also manages the access layer aspects of the Physical Networking Infrastructure (PNI). Tenants can create advanced virtual network topologies using OpenStack Networking. These topologies include services such as routers, and subnets. Each has functionality that mimics its physical counterpart. Networks contain subnets. Routers route <para>Each router has one gateway that connects to a network, and many interfaces connected to subnets. Subnets can access machines on other subnets connected to the same router.</para> This external network, unlike the other networks, is not only a virtually defined network. Instead, it provides a view into a slice of the network accessible outside the OpenStack installation, which is the outside network. IP addresses on the external network are accessible by anybody physically on the outside network. DHCP is disabled on this network.</para> <para>Machines can access the outside network through the gateway for the router. For the outside network to access VMs, and for VM's to access the outside network, routers between the networks are needed.</para> <para>Additionally, you can allocate IP addresses on external connected to a subnet, that connection is called a port.You can associate external network IP addresses with ports to VMs. This way, entities on the outside network can access VMs.</para> groups</emphasis>. Security groups enable administrators to define firewall rules in groups. A VM can belong to one or more <title>Networking plug-ins</title> <para>Each plug-in that Networking uses has its own concepts. While not vital to operating Networking, understanding these concepts can help you set up Networking. All Networking installations use a core plug-in and a security group plug-in (or just the No-Op security group plug-in). Additionally, Firewall-as-a-service (FWaaS) and

Each has functionality that mimics its physical counterpart: networks contain subnets, and routers route This network, unlike the other networks, is not merely a virtually defined network. Instead, it represents the view into a slice of the external network that is accessible outside the OpenStack installation. Because this network merely represents a slice of the outside network, DHCP is disabled on this network.</para> <para>For the outside network to access VMs, and vice versa, routers between the networks are needed. Each router has one gateway that is connected to a network and many interfaces that are connected to subnets. Like a physical router, subnets can access machines on other subnets that are connected to the same router, and machines can access the outside network through the gateway for the router.</para> <para>Additionally, you can allocate IP addresses on external connected to a subnet, that connection is called a port. commit_message:
be opinionated: only use get-pip.py

get-pip.py is now on a CDN, and is the prefered way to get pip.

Remove the default path of using pip tarballs from pypi and use
get-pip.py on from here on.

Closes-Bug: #1326539

(cherry picked from commit 7b63c5ec9e9aea54024105a6521a754efc9f9983)

Change-Id: I0661f7c6913ba6b3e1d00b30e22740d150bfd060
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/11/98211/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: PIP_GET_PIP_URL=https://bootstrap.pypa.io/get-pip.pyinstall_get_pip
deleted_lines: # Handle arguments INSTALL_PIP_VERSION=${INSTALL_PIP_VERSION:-"1.4.1"} while [[ -n "$1" ]]; do case $1 in --force) FORCE=1 ;; --pip-version) INSTALL_PIP_VERSION="$2" shift ;; --use-get-pip) USE_GET_PIP=1; ;; esac shift done PIP_GET_PIP_URL=https://raw.github.com/pypa/pip/master/contrib/get-pip.py PIP_TAR_URL=https://pypi.python.org/packages/source/p/pip/pip-$INSTALL_PIP_VERSION.tar.gzfunction install_pip_tarball() { (cd $FILES; \ curl -O $PIP_TAR_URL; \ tar xvfz pip-$INSTALL_PIP_VERSION.tar.gz 1>/dev/null; \ cd pip-$INSTALL_PIP_VERSION; \ sudo python setup.py install 1>/dev/null; \ ) } if [[ -n "$USE_GET_PIP" ]]; then install_get_pip else install_pip_tarball fi
